name: Tough World History Online Quiz | History | 25 Questions

questions.text: Beijing-man, homo erectus, was the earliest remains found in China. In what cave were the remains unearthed, in 1930?
questions.explanation: Zhoukoudian.

questions.text: Which Egyptian king ruled for the longest period?
questions.explanation:
Pepi II.

	Pepi II reigned from BC 2278-2184, in other words for 94 years - an amazing feat.

questions.text: Who lived ca. 551-479 B.C. and authored the 'Lunyu'?
questions.explanation:
Confucius.

	Confucius, or Kong Qiu, was the author of the 'Lunyu', better known as the 'Analects'. He also edited the 'Record of Rites', 'Spring and Autumn Annals', and made commentaries for the 'I-Ching'.

questions.text: What did the Kahun and Ebers papyrus, circa 1850 B.C., deal with?
questions.explanation:
medicine.

	The Ebers papyrus lists 700 remedies, from snake bites to puerpal fever. The Kahaun papyrus contains lists of such diverse items as suppositories and contraceptive devices.

questions.text: What civilization is considered the oldest in the world?
questions.explanation:
Mohenjo-daro.

	Many believe the Sumerians derived their culture from India. Mesopotamia represents a late stage of the Mohenjo-daro culture, which was derived somewhere in the area of modern Baluchistan.

questions.text: What is the oldest work on philosophy, which was completed some time between 2880 - 2300 B.C.?
questions.explanation:
Instructions from Ptahotep.

	Ptah Hotepep was the governor of ancient Memphis in the 5th Dynasty. His ideas were similar to Socrates, Buddha, and Christ.

questions.text: Who was the Babylonian king that unified the northern border of Sumer and established the capital at Akkad around 2371 B.C.?
questions.explanation: Sargon.

questions.text: During India's Heroic Age, ca. 1000-500 B.C., what class of people were on the highest caste?
questions.explanation: warriors.

questions.text: Whose death signified the beginning of the middle ages for India, until her unification by Babur?
questions.explanation:
Harsha Vardhana.

	Harsha would take out the surplus from the state treasury and place it in the marketplace to dole out. It would take several months to dole out, and people came from every part of India to receive more money than they could carry away.

questions.text: What is the name for the civilization that existed from 1200 - 300 B.C. and occupied the area later dominated by the Incas?
questions.explanation:
Chavin.

	The Chavin are named for the Chavin de Huantar site that was excavated in a small valley on the eastern slopes of the Peruvian Andes. The Moche existed there, but later than the Chavin.

questions.text: Babylon, 'Gate of God', was founded, according to myth, by the god Marduk who received a book on philosophy from a half-fish creature. What was the name of this creature?
questions.explanation: Oannes.

questions.text: What was the name of the set of Babylonian codes written on black diorite with 282 articles of conduct, ca. 1751 B.C.?
questions.correct: Hammurabi & Code of Hammurabi & Hammurabi's Code & Hammurabi Code
questions.explanation: Hammurabi & Code of Hammurabi & Hammurabi's Code & Hammurabi Code.

questions.text: What principality laid down the administration of China, and helped coalesce the broken country into one nation ca. 200 B.C.?
questions.explanation:
Qin.

	From Qin (Ch'in), we derive the term for the modern country, Chin-a.

questions.text: The I-Ching, Book of Changes, was written by a prisoner in jail. He took the 8 trigrams invented by Fu Hsi, and expanded it to 64. He was also the founder of the Zhou Dynasty. Who was he?
questions.explanation: Wen.

questions.text: What is the name of the neolithic village on Orkney island that was unearthed by a great storm in 1850?
questions.explanation:
Skara Brae.

	All items in the village, from houses, to furniture, and even utensils were made from stone, as there were no trees available on the island.

questions.text: Which ancient people under King Mursilis I sacked Babylon in 1595 B.C.?
questions.explanation: Hittites.

questions.text: Which Egyptian king was Tutankhamen's father?
questions.explanation: Akhenaton.

questions.text: Where did the first European state emerge ca. 2000 B.C.?
questions.explanation: Crete.

questions.text: The Urnfield culture emerged within the boundaries of what modern country ca. 1350 B.C.?
questions.explanation:
Hungary.

	The Urnfield culture received its name as a result of its unusual burial practices. The bodies of the dead were cremated and the ashes were placed in urns which were buried in flat fields. Some of these cemetaries number in the thousands of urns.

questions.text: Tyre, Sidon and Byblos were all ancient cities of what civilization?
questions.explanation: Phoenicia.

questions.text: Which civilization used what we now call 'Linear A' script?
questions.explanation:
Minoan.

	The Mycenaean script is called 'Linear B'.

questions.text: What was the latest period of the Japanese Jomon culture called?
questions.explanation: Banki.

questions.text: Which biblical king captured Jerusalem and made it his capital?
questions.explanation: David.

questions.text: The world's oldest pottery culture existed in what is now which modern country?
questions.explanation:
Japan.

	Evidence of pottery created as far back as 11,000 B.C. has been unearthed in Japan. This culture of hunter-gatherers is called the Jomon culture.

questions.text: What was the oldest and largest city of ancient Sumeria?
questions.explanation:
Uruk.

	The earliest period of Mesopotamian culture is thus called the 'Uruk period'.
